Bio-inspired nano-engineering of an ultrahigh loading 3D hierarchical Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 electrode for high energy density supercapacitors†
Tong Tang,a,b Shizhong Cui,a Weihua Chen, *b Hongwei Hou b and Liwei Mi *a
Energy density has become a critical barrier in supercapacitor engineering and improvement of the elec-
trode-loading is urgently demanded. However, there is conflict between the high loading and good electrochemical properties of supercapacitors. Herein, ultrahigh loading (10.33 mg·cm−2) 3D hierarchical
NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 on Ni foam with outstanding performance is obtained via bio-inspired nano-engineering, which contains compact nanowire arrays catching urchin-like micro-particles. Using this high-loading material as a binder-free electrode achieves excellent areal capacitances with 16.90 F·cm−2 at 10.33 mA·cm−2 and 1.17 F·cm−2 at 5.17 mA·cm−2 in a three-electrode system and asymmetric supercapacitor device, respectively. The device also exhibits a high energy density of 4.69 W h m−2 (power density of 10.33 W·m−2) and an outstanding stability of 91.4% after 8000 cycles (20.66 mA·cm−2). Its
excellent performance is attributed to the well-designed structure and composition: (i) a large contact
area with the electrolyte raises the utilization efficiency of the active material, therefore guaranteeing the
high capacitance of the active materials; (ii) the high electronic conductivity network constructed through
NiCo2S4 and the short diffusion length boost its rate performance; (iii) the reserved space in the hierarchical structure could hold the volume change and enhance the cycling performance of the electrode in the
charge/discharge cycles. Thus, this work not only provides a method for the construction of a high-
loading and high-performance electrode for asymmetric supercapacitors, but could also shed light on
the design of compact nano-materials for other energy storage systems.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
A supercapacitor is a promising type of energy storage device owing to its high power characteristics, long cycling life and environmental friendliness.1–4 However, its energy density (E) is far below that demanded by the market, especially in comparison with state-of-the-art lithium-ions batteries.5 To solve this problem, efforts have been devoted to broaden the operating voltage (V) and enhance the specific capacitance (C) because the value of E is determined by E = 1/2 × C × V2.6,7 The operating voltage mainly relies on the electrolyte of the devices, therefore, organic electrolytes have been applied in a high voltage device (∼3 V) compared with aqueous electrolytes (∼1.6 V).8 Despite this improvement, organic subjects are unstable owing to their flammability. For the sake of safety, most optimizing strategies are still focused on preparing high capacitive materials in aqueous systems and improving their electrochemical properties via structure design. Compared with electric double-layer capacitor materials, faradaic materials usually have higher theoretical capacitances. However, the loading of pseudocapacitor electrodes (faradaic materials) are restricted to boost their redox reactions and gain a high gravimetric electrochemical performance.9–14 These electrodes result in the low volumetric/areal energy density of devices, which is more meaningful for practical use. Therefore, it is essential to solve the conflict between the high loading and good electrochemical properties of pseudocapacitor materials.
The electrode materials of supercapacitors applied in aqueous systems mainly include typical carbon-based materials, conductive polymers and transition metal compounds (TMCs), such as Pind,15,16 Co3O4, 11,17 Ni3S2, 18–20 MCo2O4, 21–26 MMoO4, 27–29 and MCo2S4 (M = Ni/Co/Mn…), 29–32 and the gravimetric capacitance is elevated from ∼200 F g−1 to 2000–3000 F g−1.7,24 Recently, the majority of researchers have †Electronic supplementary information (ESI) available: Fig. S1–S5 and Table S1. See DOI: 10.1039/c8nr09754b aCenter for Advanced Materials Research, Zhongyuan University of Technology, Henan 450007, China. focused on the structural design of ultrahigh capacitive TMCs to enhance their electrochemical performance.33 For example, Zhai et al. fabricated a 3D-network ultrathin and porous Ni3S2/ CoNi2S4, which obtained a super high power density of 17.3 kW kg−1 at the energy density of 40.0 W h kg−1.19 Chen et al. synthesized a uniform hollow-urchin-like Ni1/3Co2/3 (CO3)1/2(OH)·0.11H2O electrode and achieved a long cycling life (with a capacitance retention ratio of 85.8% after 100 000 cycles).34 The structural modification also influenced the cell voltage of the device. Xia et al. modified the electrode through electrochemical oxidation and broadened the voltage of device to 0–2.6 V.35 These strategies mainly focused on the optimization of the structure or kinetics and gained high capacitive properties. However, the elevations in energy density were limited, especially on the volumetric/areal basis.
Some research has been performed to improve the volumetric/areal energy density of supercapacitors, and most of the reported electrodes are carbon-based materials.36–38 Porous carbon and graphene-based materials are conductive and tunable, which could maintain high charge-transfer paths and a good contact with the electrolyte. Murali et al. compressed the a-MEGO material to produce a dense electrode, which expressed a high volumetric capacitance (110 F cm−3) and energy density (48 W h L−1).37 Yang et al. modified the balance of the material density and the electrode thickness with the assistance of ZnCl2 and fabricated a compressed graphene electrode with a volumetric energy density of up to 64.7 W h L−1.39 The dense layered material could also be prepared using the re-stacking method. Chhowalla et al. re-stacked layered metallic 1 T phase MoS2 nanosheets and the supercapacitor delivered a high volumetric capacitance of ∼400 to ∼700 F cm−3.40 However, general pseudocapacitor materials, such as metal sulfides, are rigid, nonporous and not suitable for mechanical compression. They are usually assembled with current collectors (Ni foam/carbon cloth) to enhance the electrochemical performance. Hence, elevating the areal/volumetric loading with a maintained efficiency will improve the areal/volumetric performance. However, simple accumulation will block the ion-transfer path in the electrode and in turn decrease the capacitance. For example, the investigated materials PPy and MnO2 achieved a high mass loading of 30–40 mg cm−2, but their areal capacitances were 1.6–7.2 F cm−2 in a three-electrode system owing to the low theoretical values.41–44 Rational composition and structural design could reduce the influence of high loading. Wang et al. constructed a sphere-like Ni@NiCo2S4 electrode with maintained holes in the structure and enhanced the mass loading to 9.98 mg cm−2, however, the capacitance and stability needed be further modified.45
Herein, a high loading 3D hierarchical NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 composite, constructed via compact nanowire arrays on Ni foam catching urchin-like particles (H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2), was prepared using the hydrothermal reaction. It is noted that the special structure of the urchins allows them to adhere like hedgehogs, and the compact nanowire arrays (>6 µm in length; <30 nm in diameter) tend to catch the urchin-like
microparticles (∼3.5 µm in radius), which results in a high mass loading (10.33 mg cm−2) of the composite electrode. Furthermore, the high capacitive active electrode materials NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 with the high conductivity of NiCo2S4 combines with the basic Ni framework, and the large contact area with the electrolyte guarantees an excellent electrode performance. Therefore, as expected, this high-loading material achieves an areal capacitance of 16.90 F cm−2 at a current of 5.17 mA cm−2 in a three-electrode system and 1.17 F cm−2 at a current of 10.33 mA cm−2 in an asymmetric supercapacitor device with activated carbon as the counter electrode. Furthermore, it also shows an excellent stability of 91.4% after 8000 cycles (at a current of 20.66 mA cm−2) and an outstanding power density of 413.20 W m−2 (at an energy density of 1.19 W h m−2). The H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 is a promising high-loading electrode material for asymmetric supercapacitor devices, and the strategy is an effective method for the design of compact nanomaterials for other energy storage systems.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental section
sections.text: All of the reagents were of analytical grade and were used as received without further purification. The Ni foam was tailored into discs with a diameter of 13 mm and washed in HCl solution (2 M), ethanol, and deionized water, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.1. Synthesis of the Ni@Ni/Co-precursor
sections.text: The precursor was prepared according to a previously reported method.46 Typically, 1 mmol Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 2 mmol Co (NO3)2·6H2O, and 1 mmol urea (CO(NH2)2) were dissolved in 15 mL deionized water. Different amounts of cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) (0, 0.5, 1 and 1.5 mmol) were added into the above solution to investigate their influence on the morphology. Then, the obtained solutions were transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave with tailored Ni discs, respectively. The autoclaves were maintained at 120 °C for 6 h, and cooled to room temperature naturally. The products were then washed using deionized water, treated with ultrasound for 10 min, and dried in air at 60 °C overnight. The product prepared using 1 mmol CTAB was denoted as Ni@Ni/ Co-precursor. In addition, a series of parallel experiments with reaction times of 0, 2, 4, 6, 8 h were conducted to determine the formation mechanism of the Ni/Co-precursor with 1 mmol CTAB.

sections.heading: 2.2 Synthesis of Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2
sections.text:
The Ni@Ni/Co-precursor was transferred into a 25 mL Teflonlined stainless steel autoclave with 15 mL Na2S solution (0.1 M), and was then heated to 165 °C for 5 h and cooled down naturally. The sulfurated product was washed using deionized water, and treated with ultrasound for 1 min. Finally, the sample was dried in air at 60 °C for 6 h, and the product was denoted as Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2.

sections.heading: 2.3. Synthesis of H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2
sections.text: The sulfurated product Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 underwent another hydrothermal reaction with 0.2 mmol Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.4 mmol Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.2 mmol urea, and 0.2 mmol CTAB in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave at 120 °C for 6 h. The obtained sample was then washed with deionized water, dried in air at 60 °C overnight and annealed in air at 400 °C for 1 h to obtain the target product, H-Ni@NiCo2S4/ Ni3S2.

sections.heading: 2.4. Material characterization and electrochemical measurements
sections.text:
The crystal structures of the samples were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD) with a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray powder diffract meter and using Cu Kα irradiation at a scan rate of 4° min−1. The sample morphology was obtained using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Zeiss EVO LS-15 scanning electron microscope equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) system). The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images and the corresponding selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns were recorded using a transmission electron microscope (Tecnai G2 F20, FEI). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on the asobtained N-4 crystals using an X-ray photoelectron microscope (AXIS SUPR) with Al-Kα X-rays as the excitation source. The BET plot was obtained via Brunauer–Emmett–Teller measurements using a surface-area analyzer (ASAP-2020) at the temp-
erature of liquid nitrogen. H-Ni3S2/Co3S4, Ni3S2/Co3S4 and the Ni/Co-precursor powder were gained by scraping the H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2, Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 and Ni@Ni/Co-precursor and BET tests were performed directly.
The as-synthesized H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 was used as a binder-free electrode directly, with 2 M KOH as the electrolyte. A saturated Hg/HgO electrode and a platinum plate were used as the reference and counter electrodes in the three-electrode system. In addition, the as-synthesized H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 electrodes were assembled with activated carbon (AC) in the asymmetric supercapacitor devices. The AC counter electrode was prepared using polyvinylidene fluoride and AC at a mass ratio of 1 : 4. The amount of AC was three times that of the weight of H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were tested using a electrochemical workstation (CHI604E, Chenhua, Shanghai, China). The EIS test was carried out in a frequency range from 100 kHz to 0.005 Hz at an open circuit potential with a perturbation of 5 mV. The galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) was conducted on a LAND battery test system (CT2001A model) at room temperature.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
The 3D hierarchical NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 composite on Ni foam (H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2) was synthesized via a hydrothermal reaction and annealing process, as presented in Scheme 1a.
Scheme 1 Schematic diagram: (a) fabrication processes of the as-prepared H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2; (b) nano-engineering processes of the nanowire arrays and urchin-like particles.

Firstly, the 3D hierarchical Ni@Ni/Co-precursor was obtained with a structure of compact nanowire arrays that catches the urchin-like microparticles, and then, it was sulfurated to form Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2. In addition, a new class of NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 was grown on the 3D Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 and formed the 3D hierarchical H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2. The whole synthesis procedure was a morphology heredity process. The formation of the Ni@Ni/Co-precursor is the key to the construction of the hierarchical composite electrodes, which guarantees the dense and porous structure of the following products.
The precursor was typically synthesized via Ni/Co ions, urea and (CO(NH2)2) on Ni foam according to eqn (1)–(4), 28,29 which was confirmed as Ni1/3Co2/3(CO3)0.5(OH)·0.11H2O using XRD characterization (Fig. S1†). In this process, CTAB formed rod-like micelles in water, these then gathered anions (CO3
2−, OH−) and helped to generate longer nanowires (Fig. S3†). This naturally led to the combination of nanowire arrays and urchin-like particles (Scheme 1b), and the corresponding SEM images are presented in Fig. 1a and b. However, these were subject to limitations as the growth of the nanowire was determined by the reaction time and the shape of the CTAB micelles. On the one hand, a longer reaction time (8 h) seemed to allow the formation of long and thick nanowires (Fig. 1c), compared with a reaction time of 1 h (Fig. 1d). This relationship is also displayed in the inset of Fig. 1d, which shows that the length of the nanowires changes slowly after 6 h. On the other hand, the shape of the CTAB micelles relies on the concentration, which further influences the growth of the nanowires. As presented in the inset of Fig. 1e, the length of the nanowires illustrates a linear dependence on the concentration of CTAB. With the assistance of rodlike micelles, the nanowires formed arrays in a regular order (Fig. 1f), which, in turn, leads to the nano-engineering processes and results in the following high mass loading structure. However, when the concentration of CTAB is too high, the nanowire arrays tend to aggregate, decreasing the surface area. Considering the effect
of the reaction time and CTAB, the hierarchical Ni@Ni/Co-precursor was prepared using 1 M CTAB and a reaction time of 6 h.
COðNH2Þ2 þH2O ¼ CO2 þ 2NH3 ð1Þ
CO2 þH2O ¼ 2Hþ þ CO32 ð2Þ
NH3 þH2O ¼ NH4þ þ OH ð3Þ
2M2þ þ CO32 þ 2OH þH2O ¼ 2 MðCO3Þ0:5ðOHÞ 0:11H2O ð4Þ
H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 was synthesized with the hierarchical Ni@Ni/Co-precursor, and then investigated using field emission scanning electron microscopy, TEM/high-resolution TEM, XRD and XPS tests (Fig. 2). Fig. 2a–c demonstrates that the same morphology of urchin-like spheres (6–7 µm in diameter) were obtained. The precursor nanowire possesses a high length-to-diameter ratio nanowire (>6 µm in length; <30 nm in diameter), which results in the aggregation at the tail of the long and thin nanowires. Compared with Fig. 2a and b, the aggregated nanowires combine together to form thicker NiCo2S4 nanowires in the ion exchange process. H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 maintained the urchin-like structure; however, the former nanowires were covered with nanosheets and interweaved with new thin nanowires. The modified structure strengthened the integral skeleton and improved the specific surface area, as shown in the BET test (Fig. S4†). The scraping Ni/Co-precursor, NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 and H-NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 powders were applied in the analysis to avoid the disturbance of the Ni foam. The specific surface area of H-NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 is 26.383 m2 g−1, almost half that of the Ni/Co-precursor owing to the aggregation. However, this value is much higher than that of the NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 powder, which could be attributed to the newly generated nanosheets.
The phase and structure of H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 was tested using XRD, as shown in Fig. 2g. The reflection peaks at 26.8°,

31.6°, 38.3°, 50.5° and 55.3° can be assigned to the (2 2 0), (3 1 1), (4 0 0), (5 1 1), and (4 4 0) lattice planes of the cubic NiCo2S4 (JCPDS 20-0782). The weak reflections at 21.7° and 73.0° correspond to the (1 0 1) and (2 1 4) lattice planes of Ni3S2 (JCPDS 44-1418). In addition, the typical peaks at the 2θ value of 44.5°, 51.8° and 76.3° can be assigned to the diffraction of the (1 1 1), (2 0 0), and (2 2 0) lattice planes of the cubic Ni (JCPDS 04-0850), indicating that the Ni framework can be retained after the hydrothermal and annealing treatment. The peaks located at 37.4°, 43.2° and 62.9°, indicate the existence of a small amount of NiO after the annealing treatment. The TEM images of H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2, as shown in Fig. 2d–f, reveal that the nanowire consists of nanoparticles. The SAED pattern (Fig. 2e) shows a crystal spacing of 1.28 Å, 2.80 Å and 2.05 Å, 2.39 Å, which can be assigned to the (4 4 4), (3 1 1) lattice of NiCo2S4 and the (2 0 2), (0 0 3) lattice of Ni3S2. This result corresponds well with the SAED pattern and the XRD result, confirming that H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 consists of Ni, NiCo2S4 and Ni3S2.
The chemical bonding states of H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 were investigated using XPS. Fig. 2h shows the survey XPS spectrum in the range of 0–1200 eV. The peaks at 160.8, 531.3, 779.3 and 854.5 eV correspond to the spectrum of S 2p, O 1s, Co 2p and Ni 2p, which demonstrate the existence of S, O, Co and Ni elements in the material.47–51 The Ni 2p and Co 2p XPS spectra were fitted
using the Gaussian fitting method considering two spin–orbit doublets and two shakeup satellites (Fig. 2i, and Fig. S2†). The binding energy peaks for Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 are located at 854.1 and 871.4 eV, demonstrating the existence of both Ni2+ and Ni3+, respectively. The strong peaks at 779.2 eV for Co 2p3/2 and 795.4 eV for Co 2p1/2 confirm the presence of both Co
3+ and Co2+ in H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2. Fig. 2i shows the core-level spectrum of the S 2p region, in which the binding energies at 161.8 and 159.9 eV can be attributed to the bond between the metal and S. These results show that H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 contains C, O, Co2+, Co3+, Ni2+, Ni3+ and S2−, which is in good agreement with the EDX and mapping results (Fig. S5†).
After the successive reactions, the H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 gained a maximum mass loading of 13.7 mg, and the corresponding area loading was found to be 10.33 mg cm−2 (13 mm disc). To evaluate the electrochemical performance of the wellorganized composite electrode, the systematic electrochemical behaviors were tested both in the three-electrode system and an asymmetric device (with AC). The CV curves in the threeelectrode system (Fig. 3a) at different scan rates demonstrated that as the scan rate increased, the redox peaks shifted quickly owing to the polarization. In addition, the peak current for the H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 electrode is quite high owing to its high specific surface area and mass loading. In addition, the peaks are located in a similar position, which indicates the excellent
Fig. 2 SEM images of Ni/Co-precursor (a); Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 (b); and H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 (c). TEM images (d, e); SAED pattern (f ); and XRD pattern (g) of H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2. XPS spectra of H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2: (h) survey and (i) Ni 2p, Co 2p, and S 2p.

reaction reversibility of the material. The twin pair of redox peaks is attributed to the faradaic reaction of Co2+/Co3+/Co4+ and Ni2+/Ni3+ on the surface of the electrodes. The process can be explained as follows:52,53
NiCo2S4 þ OH þH2O ! NiS4 4xOHþ 2CoS2xOHþ e ð5Þ
CoS2xOHþ OH ! CoS2xOþH2Oþ e ð6Þ
CoS2x þ OH ! CoS2xOHþ e ð7Þ
NiS4 4x þ OH ! NiS4 4xOHþ e ð8Þ The GCD curves of the H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 electrode at different current densities are presented in Fig. 3b, which
shows a distinctly high capacitance of 16.90 F cm−2 at the current density of 0.5 A g−1. The CV curve for the Ni foam shows a small peak at 5 mV s−1 compared with H-Ni@NiCo2S4/ Ni3S2 (Fig. 3c), which demonstrates that the capacitance contributed by the Ni foam is negligible.
The H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 electrode was assembled into an asymmetric supercapacitor device with AC to evaluate the practical applications. The schematic diagram of the H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2//AC device is shown in Fig. 3d. Fig. 3e shows the typical CV curves for the H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2//AC devices at a scan rate of 2–100 mV s−1 in the potential window of 0–1.6 V. The potential polarization was gradually increased depending on the scan rate, and the shape of the
Fig. 3 Electrochemical performance of H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 in a three-electrode system: (a) CV curves at a scan rate of 0.5–10 mV s −1; (b) GCD curves at a current density of 5.16–206.53 mA cm−2; (c) CV comparison with Ni foam at 5 mV s−1; (d) schematic diagram of the H-Ni@NiCo2S4/ Ni3S2//AC device and the corresponding electrochemical performance; (e) CV curves at a scan rate of 2–100 mV s −1; (f ) GCD curves at a current density of 5.16–206.53 mA cm−2; (g) rate performance; (h) Nyquist impedance plot; and (i) the relationship between Ip and v 1/2 for the H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 electrodes. ( j) Cycle performance of H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 electrodes at a current density of 20.66 mA cm −2.

redox peaks was easily retained indicating the good reversibility of the electrochemical reaction. The redox peaks that appeared between 1.0 and 1.4 V indicate the reactions of the Ni2+/Ni3+ and Co3+/Co4+ redox couples.19,52,53 Fig. 3f shows the charge–discharge curves of H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2//AC at a current density of 5.16–206.53 mA cm−2. The slow-down line between 1–1.4 V results from the redox reactions of Ni/Coions, which corresponds to the CV curves. The rate performance, shown in Fig. 3g, indicated that the device expressed a high areal capacitance of 1.32 F cm−2 at the current density of 5.16 mA cm−2 and maintained an areal capacitance of 0.33 F cm−2 at a high current density of 206.53 mA cm−2. This good capacitive property could be attributed to the highly efficient charge-transfer path from NiCo2S4 and the short diffusion length of the newly-generated nanosheets/nanowires. As mentioned above, the nanowires in the urchin-like sphere and arrays became thicker after the modification process, which strengthened the whole structure. The newlygenerated nanowires also behaved as a morphology protector to maintain the charge-transfer path during the long cycling. Therefore, the H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 electrode demonstrated a high structural stability and long cycling life. The device exhibited an enhanced high capacitance retention of 91.4% after 8000 cycles at a current density of 20.66 mA cm−2 (Fig. 3j). The morphology evolution was surveyed and the SEM images of the H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 electrode after cycling are presented in Fig. S6.† The micro-sphere shapes of the electrode were still maintained after cycling, which resulted in a superior cycling stability and the excellent capacitance retention of the electrode.
The reaction kinetics in the electrochemical reaction were confirmed using a Nyquist impedance plot as shown in Fig. 3h, which exhibited a small real-axis intercept and an insignificant semicircle in the high-frequency region of the H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2//AC. This reveals a relatively low internal resistance and charge-transfer resistance owing to the high conductive NiCo2S4 and the in situ binder-free structural
design. In the low-frequency region, the high slope indicates an excellent capacitive performance. The good electrochemical behavior is mainly attributed to the hierarchical structure design, produced by the urchin-like particles and nanowire arrays. The void space in the as-prepared high loading material is beneficial for ion-transfer, implying high reaction kinetics, which is confirmed by the high OH− ion diffusion coefficient. The OH− ion diffusion coefficient was measured via the linear relationship between the peak currents (Ip) and the square of the scan rate (ν1/2) (Fig. 3i). The diffusion coefficient of the OH− ion can be calculated using the Randles–Sevcik equation:54–56
Ip ¼ 2:69 105 n 3=2 A D1=2 Co ν 1=2 ð9Þ
In which n is the number of electrons in the transfer process, D is the diffusion coefficient, A refers to the electrode area (cm2), and Co is the concentration of the OH
− ions (mol L−1). The OH− diffusion coefficient of the H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 electrode was calculated to be 1.702 × 10−12 cm2 s−1, corresponding to the EIS test. The electron/ion transfer path in H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 is schematically presented in Fig. 4a, which shows the structural detail from micrometer scale to the nanometer scale. The high conductivity of NiCo2S4 and the Ni framework ensure the fast electron transfer, and the void space between the nano structure can store the electrolyte and reduce polarization. As a result, the as-synthesized H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 electrode demonstrates an excellent performance with high loading.
A comparison of the asymmetrical supercapacitor presented in this work with those reported in the state-of-the-art literature is shown in the Ragone plots based on the area (Fig. 4b).57–68 The areal mass loading of the as-prepared H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 electrode (10.33 mg cm
−2) was higher than most of the Ni/Co-based electrodes (also listed in Table S1†). The energy density and power density of the asym-

metrical supercapacitor were calculated according to eqn (10) and (11):6,7,69
E ¼ 1=2 C V 2 ð10Þ P ¼ E=Δt ð11Þ
In which E is the specific energy density, C refers to the areal capacitance, V is the voltage range, P represents the power density, and Δt represents the discharge time. Obviously, the H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2//AC device achieved a high performance, which exhibited a superior energy density of 4.69 W h m−2 at a power density of 10.32 W m−2, and a high power density of 413.20 W m−2 at an energy density of 1.19 W h m−2. This result confirms that the hierarchical design is an effective approach to increase the loading and enhance the effective utilization of the electroactive materials, which is promising for practical high energy density applications.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In conclusion, a novel hierarchical NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 composite of compact nanowire arrays catching urchin-like particles on 3D Ni foam was fabricated in situ; the composite achieved an ultrahigh mass loading of 13.7 mg (10.33 mg cm−2) and was directly used as a supercapacitor electrode. The electrochemical characterization exhibits an areal capacitance of 16.90 F cm−2 (5.17 mA cm−2) in a three-electrode system and 1.17 F cm−2 (10.33 mA cm−2) in an asymmetric supercapacitor device using AC as the counter electrode; this also shows an excellent stability (91.4%, 8000 cycles, 20.66 mA cm−2) and an outstanding energy density of 4.69 W h m−2 (10.33 W m−2). Furthermore, the diffusion coefficient of OH− is relatively high (1.702 × 10−12 cm2 s−1). The good performance of the as-prepared H-Ni@NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 electrode could be attributed to the well-designed structure, the multiple composition and binderfree assembly, which formed a large contact area with the electrolyte, the short diffusion length and the conductive framework. Thus, this work not only provides a high-loading and high-performance electrode for asymmetric supercapacitors, but it could also shed light on the design of compact nanomaterials for other energy storage systems.
Conflicts of interest
There are no conflicts to declare.

metadata.abstractText: Energy density has become a critical barrier in supercapacitor engineering and improvement of the electrode-loading is urgently demanded. However, there is conflict between the high loading and good electrochemical properties of supercapacitors. Herein, ultrahigh loading (10.33 mg·cm) 3D hierarchical NiCo2S4/Ni3S2 on Ni foam with outstanding performance is obtained via bio-inspired nano-engineering, which contains compact nanowire arrays catching urchin-like micro-particles. Using this high-loading material as a binder-free electrode achieves excellent areal capacitances with 16.90 F·cm at 10.33 mA·cm and 1.17 F·cm at 5.17 mA·cm in a three-electrode system and asymmetric supercapacitor device, respectively. The device also exhibits a high energy density of 4.69 W h m (power density of 10.33 W·m) and an outstanding stability of 91.4% after 8000 cycles (20.66 mA·cm). Its excellent performance is attributed to the well-designed structure and composition: (i) a large contact area with the electrolyte raises the utilization efficiency of the active material, therefore guaranteeing the high capacitance of the active materials; (ii) the high electronic conductivity network constructed through NiCo2S4 and the short diffusion length boost its rate performance; (iii) the reserved space in the hierarchical structure could hold the volume change and enhance the cycling performance of the electrode in the charge/discharge cycles. Thus, this work not only provides a method for the construction of a highloading and high-performance electrode for asymmetric supercapacitors, but could also shed light on the design of compact nano-materials for other energy storage systems.
